title4 = Tryna Get It | note4 = featuring [[Twista]] & [[T-Pain]] | extra4 = JohnG & Haze | length4 = 3:07 | title5 = Street Nigga | extra5 = Scorp Dezel | length5 = 3:12 | title6 = The Other Day Ago | note6 = featuring [[Spice 1]] & [[Celly Cel]] | extra6 = Mike Mosley & Sam Bostic | length6 = 3:52 | title7 = This Is the Life | note7 = featuring Sam Bostic | extra7 = Sam Bostic | length7= 4:11 | title8 = Sell Everything | extra8 = [[Rick Rock]] | length8 = 4:30 | title9 = My Life | note9 = featuring R.O.D. | extra9 = Sam Bostic | length9 = 3:32 | title10 = Grey Skies | note10 = featuring Deltrice | extra10 = ReeceBeats | length10 = 3:44 | title11 = With the Shit | note11 = featuring [[JT the Bigga Figga]] & [[Cellski]] | extra11 = [[Droop-E]] | length11 = 3:26 | title12 = Hittin' A = featuring [[Dorrough]] | extra20 = C-Ballin | length20 = 4:18 }} ===Notes=== * Cousin Fik is not credited in "I'm Laced" and "This Shit Hard" * [[Stressmatic]] is not credited in "The Other Day Ago", "Sell Everything" and "Hittin' a Lick" * [[Kung Fu Vampire]] has a cameo in the "Zombie" music video, but he was not involved in the production of the song. ;Sample credits *"I'm Laced" - revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name=The Futon Critic | logo=[[File:The Futon Critic logo.gif|frameless|upright]] | screenshot= | caption= | collapsible= | url={{URL|http://www.thefutoncritic.com/}} | commercial= | type= | language=English | registration=Optional | owner=Futon Media | author=[[Brian Ford Sullivan]] | country = United States | launch date=January 14, 1997 | current status=Active | revenue= | alexa= }} '''The Futon Critic''' is a website that provides articles and information regarding prime time programming on [[broadcast programming|broadcast]] and [[cable television|cable networks]] in the United States. The site publishes [[review]]s of prime time programming and interviews of people in the television industry, as well as republishing [[Nielsen ratings]] data reports and press releases provided by television networks. ''The Futon Critic'' was founded by [[Brian Ford Sullivan]] in 1997.
==History== [[File:Nielsen logo.svg|left|thumb|upright|The site republishes ratings provided by [[Nielsen Media Research]] ''(parent company logotype pictured)''.]]
Brian Ford Sullivan, CEO of Futon Media, registered ''The Futon Critic'' on January 14, 1997.<ref name="Trademark Status and Document Retrieval 'Futon Critic'"/><ref name="Miller2010"/> From its founding, the site has published [[review]]s on prime time programming, as well as interviews its staff conducted with members of the television industry.<ref name="Lacey2007"/> The site also contains sections of articles dedicated to republishing [[press release]]s, network schedules and [[Nielsen ratings]] data, which have been cited by articles on websites such as ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' and [[TV by the Numbers]].<ref name="Harnick2012"/><ref name="Seidman2009a"/><ref name="Seidman2009b"/> Its publications of Nielsen ratings data have also been used as a resource by institutions such as the [[University of Colorado Boulder]] and [[Temple University]].<ref name="Couture 'Finding Nielsen Ratings'"/><ref name="Temple University Libraries2014"/>
In 2009, Sullivan appeared on [[WGN (AM)|WGN]]'s ''[[The Nick Digilio Show]]'' to discuss television and the [[61st Primetime Emmy Awards|Emmy nominations of the year]] on behalf of the site.<ref name="Los Angeles Times2009"/> In 2010, Sullivan announced a new section of their site dedicated to tracking the availability of programming on [[digital distribution]] platforms, to be launched in August of the same year. He also announced the production of a television pilot to be released onto the section sometime after its launch; entitled ''.comEDY'', it was pitched as a comedic look at the effects of the [[Dot-com bubble#The bubble bursts|dot-com bubble burst]] around [[Silicon Valley]].<ref name="Miller2010"/>
==References== {{reflist | colwidth=30em | refs= <ref name="Couture 'Finding Nielsen Ratings'">{{cite web |url = http://ucblibraries.colorado.edu/research/subjectguides/journalism/nielsen.htm |title = Finding Nielsen Ratings |publisher = [[University of Colorado-Boulder]] Libraries |accessdate = March 21, 2014 |author = Couture, Juliann |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140322001305/http://ucblibraries.colorado.edu/research/subjectguides/journalism/nielsen.htm |archivedate = March 22, 2014 |df = }}</ref> <ref name="Harnick2012">{{cite journal | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/29/bristol-palin-reality-show-bumped-dance-moms-reruns_n_1638198.html | title=Bristol Palin's Reality Show Bumped For ''Dance Moms'' Reruns | work=[[The Huffington Post]] | date=June 29, 2012 | accessdate=March 21, 2014 | author=Harnick, Chris | location=New York City }}</ref> <ref name="Lacey2007">{{cite web |url = http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Ed/7005 |title = The Futon Critic reports on more ''Ed'' news |publisher = [[CBS Interactive]] |work = [[TVShowsOnDVD.com]] |date = March 9, 2007 |accessdate = March 21, 2014 |author = Lacey, Gord |location = New York City |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140322001527/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Ed/7005 |archivedate = March 22, 2014 |df = }}</ref> <ref name="Los Angeles Times2009">{{cite news | url=http://www.latimes.com/wgnam-nickd-pictures-sullivan-090718,0,5599412.photo | title=Brian Ford Sullivan | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=July 18, 2009 | accessdate=March 21, 2014 }}</ref> <ref name="Miller2010">{{cite web | url=http://gigaom.com/2010/05/06/tv-expert-thefutoncritic-com-to-add-online-listings-original-content/ | title=TV Expert TheFutonCritic.com to Add Online Listings, Original Content | publisher=[[Gigaom]] | date=May 6, 2010 | accessdate=March 21, 2014 | author=Miller, Liz Shannon | location=San Francisco }}</ref> <ref name="Seidman2009a">{{cite web | url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2009/10/21/will-fox-bench-dollhouse-for-november-sweeps-after-all/31184/ | title=Fox benches ''Dollhouse'' for November sweeps after all | publisher=[[Tribune Media Services]] | work=[[TV by the Numbers]] | date=October 21, 2009 | accessdate=March 21, 2014 | author=Seidman, Robert | location=San Francisco }}</ref> <ref name="Seidman2009b">{{cite web | url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2009/11/17/burn-notice-returns-january-28th-to-be-paired-with-white-collar/33840/ | title=The Futon Critic reports ''Burn Notice'' returns January 28, to be paired with ''White Collar'' | publisher=[[Tribune Media Services]] | work=TV by the Numbers | date=November 17, 2009 | accessdate=March 21, 2014 | author=Seidman, Robert | location=San Francisco }}</ref> <ref name="Temple University Libraries2014">{{cite web | url=http://guides.temple.edu/content.php?pid=3635&sid=51342 | title=Nielsen Ratings | publisher=[[Temple University]] Libraries | date=February 5, 2014 | accessdate=March 21, 2014 | location=Philadelphia }}</ref> <ref name="Trademark Status and Document Retrieval 'Futon Critic'">{{cite web | url=http://tsdr.uspto.gov/#caseNumber=78945981&caseType=SERIAL_NO&searchType=statusSearch | title=[The] Futon Critic | publisher=[[United States Patent and Trademark Office]] | work=Trademark [[The Movie Network]] | distributor = | channel = [[Syfy (UK and Ireland)|Sci Fi Channel]] (United Kingdom)
The Movie Network (Canada) [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] (United States) | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = July 20, 1997 | last_aired = March 5, 2000 | status = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = | production_website = }} '''''The Hunger''''' is a [[Television in the United Kingdom|British]]/[[Television in Canada|Canadian]] [[television]] [[Horror film|horror]] [[anthology series]], co-produced by [[Scott Free Productions]], [[Telescene|Telescene Film Group Productions]] and the Canadian pay-TV channel [[The Movie Network]]. It was created by [[Jeff Fazio]]. Originally shown on the [[Sci Fi Channel (United Kingdom)|Sci Fi Channel]] in the UK, [[The Movie Network]] in Canada and [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] in the US, the series was broadcast from 1997 to 2000, and is internally organized into two seasons. Each episode was based around an independent story introduced by the host; [[Terence Stamp]] hosted each episode for the first season, and was replaced in the second season by [[David Bowie]]. Stories tended to focus on themes of self-destructive desire and obsession, with a strong component of soft-core [[erotica]]; popular tropes for the stories included [[cannibalism]], [[vampires]], sex, and poison. ==Episodes== ===Season 1 (1997–1998)=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%; margin:auto; background:#ffffff;" |- !style="background-color: #834752; color: #ffffff;" | Series

Four years later, though, he revisits them to see how they fared and finds their relationship is troubled. Was his mistake just that... Or is his poor matchmaking deliberate?. Stars Claudia Besso, Aldo Tirelli and Noël Burton. |LineColor=88C9A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=39 |EpisodeNumber2=17 |Title= The Sacred Fire |DirectedBy=[[Russell Mulcahy]] |WrittenBy=[[Charles de Lint]] |OriginalAirDate={{start date|2000|01|30}} |ProdCode=040 |ShortSummary= Luann is a kind and generous woman who volunteers to help the homeless find food and shelter, but when she meets Nick, who lives on the street, he warns her that there are street people who are actually demons in disguise, intent on killing humans. Stars Kim Huffman and [[James Marshall (actor)|James Marshall]]. |LineColor=88C9A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=40 |EpisodeNumber2=18 |Title=Approaching Desdemona |DirectedBy=Jason Hreno |WrittenBy= Lenny Kleinfeld (Story)
Terry Curtis Fox (Teleplay) |OriginalAirDate={{start date|2000|02|06}} |ProdCode=027 |ShortSummary= In a story that will be familiar to many Internet users, a couple's life together deteriorates when he finds an adult website that offers bizarre sexual fantasies. Stars Christina Colburn, [[William McNamara]] and April Telek. |LineColor=88C9A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=41 |EpisodeNumber2=19 |Title=The Seductress |DirectedBy=Alain Desrochers |WrittenBy= Ramsey Campbell (Story)
Mark Nelson (Teleplay) |OriginalAirDate={{start date|2000|02|13}} |ProdCode=030 |ShortSummary= When a novelist reads a suicide note from a former lover, she begins an affair with a mysterious man, but their romance is not all it seems and the boundaries between reality and fiction appear to fall away. Stars [[William Katt]], Laura Mitchell and [[Rachel Hayward]]. |LineColor=88C9A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=42 |EpisodeNumber2=20 |Title= Double |DirectedBy=John L'Ecuyer |WrittenBy= [[Karl Edward Wagner]] (Story)
Bruce M. Smith (Teleplay) |OriginalAirDate={{start date|2000|02|20}} |ProdCode=042 |ShortSummary= The myth of the [[Doppelganger]] has lasted for centuries and receives a modern updating here as two identical women meet but realise the differences between them are in their personalities - one is normal whilst the other is plagued by nightmares. Their meeting, however, results in a battle for their souls. Stars [[Lori Petty]], [[Daniela Akerblom]], Larry Day, and [[Rachelle Lefevre]]. |LineColor=88C9A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=43 |EpisodeNumber2=21 |Title=The Falling Man |DirectedBy=[[Daniel Grou]] |WrittenBy= Bruce M. Smith (Teleplay)
David J. Schow (Story) |OriginalAirDate={{start date|2000|02|27}} |ProdCode=035 |ShortSummary= A muse inspires a gifted young architect, but she exacts a terrible price from him when he fails. Stars Maria Bertrand and [[A Martinez]]. |LineColor=88C9A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=44 |EpisodeNumber2=22 |Title=The Suction Method |DirectedBy= Darrell Wasyk |WrittenBy= Rudy Kremberg (Story)
Gerald Wexler (Teleplay) |OriginalAirDate={{start date|2000|03|05}} |ProdCode=037 |ShortSummary= A middle-aged married man cheats on his wife with the carpet cleaner lady. But there's a bigger story behind the mysterious lady---she's there to get the unwanted "dirt" out of the house. Stars [[Fisher Stevens]], Jeannie Walker and Valérie Valois. |LineColor=88C9A1 }} |} ==DVD releases== '''Region 1''' [[Entertainment One]] released both seasons on DVD in the US in 2009. Season 1 was released on June 2, 2009 and Season 2 on October 13, 2009. [[Alliance Films|Alliance Home Entertainment]] has released the entire series on DVD in Canada for the very first time. '''Region 2''' [[Infinity Video]] released both seasons on DVD in the UK for the very first time on October 31, 2005 as Amazon exclusives.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B000BEVZZE|title=The Hunger - Complete Series 1 Box Set|date=31 October 2005|publisher=|accessdate=4 July 2016|via=Amazon}}{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B000BEVZZO|title=The Hunger - Complete Series 2 Box Set|date=31 October 2005|publisher=|accessdate=4 July 2016|via=Amazon}} Season 1 and 2 were re-released as full retail releases in 2007. {| class="wikitable" !rowspan="2"|DVD Name !rowspan="2"|Ep# !colspan="3"|Release Dates |- ! {{About|the documentary film||Tickle (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}}{{Infobox film | name = Tickled | image = Tickled.png | alt = movie poster, depicting the face of a man, his mouth covered by a cloth gag with the word 'tickled' superimposed over it | caption = New Zealand theatrical release poster | directors = [[David Farrier]]
Dylan Reeve | producer = [[Carthew Neal]] | distributors = [[Magnolia Pictures]] (US) | writer = | narrator = David Farrier | music = | cinematography = Dominic Fryer | editing = Simon Coldrick | studio = A Ticklish Tale
Fumes Production
Horseshoe Films | released = {{Film date|2016|5|27}} | runtime = 92 minutes | country = New Zealand | language = English | budget = | gross = $923,000{{cite web |url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Tickled-(2016)#tab=summary |title=Tickled |website=The-Numbers |accessdate=September 30, 2016}} }} '''''Tickled''''' is a 2016 New Zealand [[documentary]] about "competitive endurance [[tickling]]" and videos featuring it, and the practices of those producing the videos, directed by [[David Farrier]] and Dylan Reeve. The film explores possible legal and ethical issues with certain individuals making the videos, and has itself been the subject of legal challenges. A follow-up special, ''The Tickle King'', aired on [[HBO]] in February 2017.{{Citation|last=Tickled|title=The Tickle King|date=2017-06-27|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K88xF9mOUjc|accessdate=2017-11-19}}{{cite web|url=https://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/tickled-documentary-draws-controversy-1.13185248|title=Controversy surrounds ‘Tickled’ documentary|author=|date=|website=newsday.com|accessdate=27 July 2018}} ==Synopsis== David Farrier, a New Zealand television reporter whose beat focuses on "quirky and odd stories", sees videos online about an activity described as "competitive endurance tickling", in which young athletic men are restrained and tickled by each other; he begins to research it for a story. He requests for an interview with the videos' producer Jane O'Brien Media, but the company refused to "associate with a homosexual journalist"{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/is-tickled-next-catfish-892892|title=Is 'Tickled' Poised to Be the Next 'Catfish'?|author=|date=|website=hollywoodreporter.com|accessdate=27 July 2018}} (Farrier is actually bisexual{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501119&objectid=11459066|title=Why David Farrier gave up med school for journalism|last=Perrott|first=Alan|date=2015-06-06|work=New Zealand Herald|access-date=2017-03-02|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777}}). Since Farrier considers the act of tickling other men "pretty gay," he is confused and offended by the hostile response, but intrigued. Farrier partners with television producer Dylan Reeve to learn more about tickling videos and the people who produce them. After blogging about the incident, they receive legal threats from Jane O'Brien Media, who send Kevin Clarke and two other representatives to New Zealand. Although their interactions are superficially cordial, the Jane O'Brien Media people seem intent on bullying the investigators into dropping the project. Farrier and Reeve respond by traveling to Los Angeles, and find the representatives at a site where the company records videos, but are turned away at the door. Researching the phenomenon further, they uncover information about a person known as Terri DiSisto (alias "Terri Tickle"), who pioneered recruiting and distributing tickling videos online in the 1990s. They interview independent tickling-video producer Richard Ivey whose operations are a low-key affair with an acknowledged homoerotic aspect. They speak to a few former participants in Jane O'Brien Media's videos who describe coercive and manipulative treatment by the producers, such as defamation campaigns against them, exposing their personal information and contacting school or work associates to discredit them as homosexual or as sexual deviants, in retaliation for challenging or speaking out against the company. A local recruiter in [[Muskegon, Michigan]], describes "audition" videos he had helped make, which were published by O'Brien Media without the participants' consent. Farrier and Reeve chance upon documents on a defunct tickling-video web site, which link Jane O'Brien Media to [[David D'Amato]], the former school administrator behind the "Terri Tickle" alias. They learn that D'Amato had served a six-month prison sentence for disabling computer systems at two different universities on multiple dates, in retaliation against an 18-year-old male student who attempted to terminate their online relationship, begun when the young man was 17.Brian McWilliams (2004). Spam Kings: The Real Story behind the High-Rolling Hucksters Pushing Porn, Pills, and %*@)# Enlargements. O'Reilly. {{ISBN|978-0-596-00732-4}}.{{Cite web|url=https://mycitypaper.com/articles/040501/cb.onmedia.shtml|title=Who’s Laughing Now?|last=Scoblionkov|first=Deborah|website=mycitypaper.com|access-date=2016-09-01}} They determine that D'Amato now lives on a substantial inheritance from his father, a successful lawyer.{{cite web|url=https://www.indiewire.com/2017/03/david-damato-dead-tickled-villian-died-1201794767/|title=David D’Amato, the Villain of ‘Tickled,’ ‘Died Suddenly’ at Age 55|first=William|last=Earl|date=18 March 2017|website=indiewire.com|accessdate=27 July 2018}} After considerable effort to locate him, they confront him on the street, to which he responds with additional legal threats. Before returning to New Zealand, Farrier contacts D'Amato's stepmother for comment; she implicitly confirms her stepson's "tickling" past, and Farrier informs her that he believes D'Amato is still involved in it. ==Production== Under the working title ''Tickle King: The Hunt for the Truth in Competitive Tickling'', Farrier and Reeve raised [[New Zealand dollar|NZ$]]29,570 on [[Kickstarter]] in June 2014, intended primarily to cover the costs of the crew traveling to the United States for a week.{{Cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/dylanreeve/tickle-king-the-hunt-for-the-truth-in-competitive|title=Project page on kickstarter}} The project also received funding from the [[New Zealand Film Commission]]. The soundtrack includes music from ''[[Upstream Color]]'' by [[Shane Carruth]]. ==Release== The film was screened at the January 2016 [[Sundance Film Festival]], after which [[Magnolia Pictures]] picked up distribution and HBO picked up US TV rights.{{cite news|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2016/01/magnolia-pictures-and-hbo-pick-up-sundance-doc-tickled-28418/|title=Magnolia Pictures and HBO Pick Up Sundance Doc ‘Tickled’|last=Sharf|first=Zack|date=31 January 2016|work=[[IndieWire]]|accessdate=12 July 2016}} In March 2016 it was presented as part of the [[True/False Film Festival]]. The film was released to New Zealand theaters on 27 May 2016. It was released by [[Magnolia Pictures]] to US theaters on 17 June, and in Australia and the United Kingdom on 19 August. ==Reception== ''Tickled'' has received critical acclaim. In a review headlined "fetish documentary goes from giggly to grim", Nigel Smith of ''[[The Guardian]]'' gives the movie four (of five) stars.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/08/tickled-documentary-review-david-farrier-cyberbullying|title=Tickled review: fetish documentary goes from giggly to grim|last=Smith|first=Nigel|date=8 Mar 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=12 July 2016}} Dennis Harvey of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' states the onscreen presence of the filmmakers "is justified because the harassment they experience in pursuing the story becomes a big part of its narrative".{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/markets-festivals/tickled-review-1201685765/|title=‘Tickled’ Review: An Engrossing Investigative Doc|last=Harvey|first=Dennis|date=24 Jan 2016|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=12 July 2016}} ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]'', giving it 4.5 stars, said it was "an act of journalistic courage" and that they "reveal the harm that can be done by an individual with a lot of money and a vindictive streak".{{cite news|url=http://www.sltrib.com/blogs/3480007-155/sundance-16-review-tickled|title=Sundance '16 review: 'Tickled'|date=30 January 2016|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|accessdate=12 July 2016}} [[Manohla Dargis]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'', giving it a Critic's Pick, said "Farrier and Mr. Reeve see the humor, but they also see the pathos—because it's all fun and giggles until someone gets hurt."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/17/movies/tickled-review.html|title=Review: ‘Tickled’ Is Fun and Giggles Until It Isn’t Anymore|last=Dargis|first=Manohla|date=16 June 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=12 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/tickled-sundance-review-857740|title='Tickled': Sundance Review|author=|date=|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|access-date=27 July 2018}} [[Armond White]] of ''[[Out (magazine)|Out]]'' magazine was critical of the movie, commenting that it "zips past its sexual aspects", and concluding that it is ultimately "frustrating, a blue-balls documentary".{{cite news|url=http://www.out.com/armond-white/2016/6/24/tickling-hbo-documentary-gay|title=Sports Documentary 'Tickled' Exploits Fetishism and Gay Teasing|last=White|first=Armond|date=24 June 2016|work=[[Out (magazine)|Out]]|accessdate=12 July 2016}} At [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film has an approval rating of 93% based on reviews from 106 critics.{{Cite web|title=Tickled|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/tickled/|language=en|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=2017-11-19}} [[Metacritic]] gives the film a score of 76 out of 100, based on reviews from 28 critics, indicating "generally favorable" reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/tickled|title=Tickled|author=|date=|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=27 July 2018}}
The shocking truth is uncomfortably pursued to its fullest, and the result is a riveting piece of investigative journalism.{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2017/03/weekend-stream-the-tickle-king-gorrilaz/|title=Weekend Stream: This Tickling Documentary and Its Even More Bizarre Follow-Up|author=|date=24 March 2017|website=[[New York Observer]]|accessdate=27 July 2018}} :— Darian Lusk, ''[[New York Observer]]''
==Response from the documentary's subjects== In the movie, D'Amato is seen accusing Farrier of being in America illegally, by using a [[travel visa#Short-stay or visitor visas|tourist visa]] for journalism. Farrier, who routinely travels internationally on assignment, states he was on a [[travel visa#Long-stay visas|journalist visa]]. Farrier also shows documents from O'Brien Media, coaching international video participants to travel under a tourist visa when coming to the US for paid performances. After the premiere screening at Sundance, in March 2016, D'Amato filed a federal lawsuit against the filmmakers for making false accusations, including the implication that D'Amato used extortion and abused minors, and stating that D'Amato has no relationship with O'Brien Media. In response, Farrier told ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]'' that "given the number of hollow legal threats we faced during the making of it, it's almost refreshing to see a real case being filed by real lawyers."{{cite news|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/3635058-155/sundance-film-on-competitive-endurance-tickling?fullpage=1|title=Sundance film on 'competitive endurance tickling' is defamatory, suit alleges|last=Manson|first=Pamela|date=11 March 2016|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|accessdate=12 July 2016}} In June 2016, Kevin Clarke of O'Brien Media created a website to counter the documentary.{{cite news|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2016/05/tickled-campaign-launched-to-try-to-discredit-provocative-competitive-tickling-documentary-288905/|title=‘Tickled’: Campaign Launched To Try To Discredit Provocative Competitive Tickling Documentary|last=Winfrey|first=Graham|date=23 May 2016|work=[[IndieWire]]|accessdate=12 July 2016}} D'Amato attended the 18 June 2016 screening at the [[Nuart Theater]] in Los Angeles, and confronted Dylan Reeve, saying, "You need to lawyer up. You need to get criminal counsel." Clarke argued with Reeve during a public question-and-answer session after the film, saying "The film is a piece of garbage full of lies. Release the audio tapes that show you're lying. And if you don't release it, it's the same as admitting you're lying."{{cite news|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/81212098/tickled-creator-dylan-reeve-confronted-by-subject-of-movie-at-premiere|title=Tickled creator Dylan Reeve confronted by the subject of his documentary at premiere|last=Fagan|first=Josh|date=18 June 2016|work=[[Stuff.co.nz]]|accessdate=12 July 2016}} D'Amato filed a $40 million defamation and slander lawsuit in Nassau County court alleging that his stepmother Dorothy D'Amato made statements in the film with the intention to injure his business, causing mental distress.{{cite news|last1=Siegler|first1=Mara|title=Competitive tickling film sparks another defamation suit|url=http://pagesix.com/2016/06/15/competitive-tickling-film-sparks-another-defamation-suit/|accessdate=26 February 2017|work=Page Six|date=16 June 2016}}{{cite news|last1=O'Sullivan|first1=Michael|title=He made a movie about competitive tickling. But then things got truly weird.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/he-made-a-movie-about-competitive-tickling-but-then-things-got-truly-weird/2016/06/30/0a622a0c-3d56-11e6-84e8-1580c7db5275_story.html|accessdate=26 February 2017|work=The Washington Post|date=30 June 2016}} D'Amato died at age 55, on 13 March 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://thespinoff.co.nz/society/19-06-2017/life-after-the-tickle-kings-death/|title=Life after the Tickle King's death|date=2017-06-19|work=The Spinoff|access-date=2018-04-02|language=en-US}} The filmmakers posted a statement on their web site that they were "incredibly sad" to learn of it, and asking that his death be treated with respect.{{Cite news|url=https://tickledmovie.com/statement/|title=Tickled|work=Tickled|access-date=2017-03-18|language=en-US}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official}} * {{IMDb title}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes}} * {{YouTube|K88xF9mOUjc|The Tickle King}}, follow-up special [[Category:New Zealand documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about sexuality]] [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:Tickling]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1) ([[User:Josve05a|Josve05a]])
revision.text:
'''Worm charming''', '''worm grunting''', and '''worm fiddling''' are methods of attracting [[earthworm]]s from the ground. The activity is usually performed to collect [[fishing lure|bait]] for [[fishing]] but can also take the form of a competitive [[sport]] in areas such as [[east Texas]]. As a skill and profession worm charming is now very rare, with the art being passed through generations to ensure that it survives.<ref name="ESPN">Sutton, Keith. [[ESPN]]. 20 March 2007. "[http://sports.espn.go.com/outdoors/fishing/columns/story?columnist=sutton_keith&page=g_col_Sutton_fiddling_for_worms Fiddling For Worms]". Accessed 7 June 2007.</ref><ref name="MotherEarth">Phillips, John E. MotherEarthNews.com. 1 May 1980. "[http://www.motherearthnews.com/Homesteading-and-Self-Reliance/1980-05-01/Fiddling-For-Fish-Bait.aspx Fiddling for fish bait] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930203514/http://www.motherearthnews.com/Homesteading-and-Self-Reliance/1980-05-01/Fiddling-For-Fish-Bait.aspx |date=2007-09-30 }}". Accessed 7 June 2007.</ref>
==Methods== [[File:Florida worm charming example.webm|frame|right|Two people worm grunting to collect bait in the [[Apalachicola National Forest]]. The worms respond to vibrations created by rubbing the top of a wooden stake with a flat piece of metal]] Most worm charming methods involve [[vibration|vibrating]] the [[soil]], which encourages the worms to the surface. In 2008 researchers from Vanderbilt University claimed that the worms surface because the vibrations are similar to those produced by digging [[mole (animal)|moles]], which prey on earthworms.<ref>Catania KC (2008) [http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0003472 "Worm Grunting, Fiddling, and Charming—Humans Unknowingly Mimic a Predator to Harvest Bait."] PLoS ONE 3(10): e3472. {{doi|10.1371/journal.pone.0003472}}</ref><ref>Fountain, Henry. ''The New York Times.'' 17 October 2008. [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/18/science/21wormgrunting.html "Worm Grunting: A Mystery Solved"]</ref> The same technique is used by many species of bird, which devour the worms as they appear above ground.<ref name="ESPN" />
The activity is known by several different names and the apparatus and techniques vary significantly.<ref name="ESPN" /><ref name="MotherEarth" /> "Worm grunting" generally refers to the use of a "stob", a wooden stake that is driven into the ground, and a "rooping iron" which is used to rub the stob.<ref name="sptimes">Tobin, Thomas C. ''St. Petersburg Times''. 14 April 2002. "[http://www.sptimes.com/2002/04/14/State/Gruntin__and_gatherin.shtml Gruntin' and gathering]". Accessed 7 June 2007.</ref> "Worm fiddling" also uses a wooden stake but utilises a dulled [[saw]] which is dragged along its top.<ref name="ESPN" />
Techniques vary from sprinkling the turf with water, tea and beer, to music or just "twanging" with a garden fork.<ref name=Berrington>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4161/is_19960428/ai_n14451942 ''Sunday Mirror'', "The war of the worms" article by Lucy Berrington, April 28, 1996]</ref> In some organized competitions, detergents and mechanical diggers have been banned.<ref name=Berrington/>
==Animal behavior== Worm charming is a behavior also observed in the animal kingdom, especially among birds. The methods used vary; however, tapping earth with feet to generate vibrations is widespread. One common example is the "[[Seagull]] dance". The [[wood turtle]] also seems to be adapted for worm charming, as it is known to stamp its feet – a behavior that attracts worms to the surface and allows the turtle to prey on them.
==Soil conditions== Worms are most commonly found in damp or wet conditions and tend to move away from dry soil. The success of worm charming can often depend on these soil conditions, with charmers choosing damp locations or using water to attract the worms.<ref name="ESPN" /><ref name="MotherEarth" /><ref name="sptimes" />
==Worm charming as a profession== Worms are sold as a live bait for fishermen, and many sellers use worm charming techniques to gather their stock. In some locations professional worm grunters need to obtain a permit in order to ply their trade.<ref name="sptimes" />
==Competitive worm charming== In most competitions the fiddlers with the collector (or collectors) of the most worms in a set time being declared as the winners. They usually have a zone in which to perform their charming, measuring three yards square.
[[File:Willaston_-_Worm_Charming.jpg|thumb|Competitive worm charming at Willaston]] One of the first worm charming events took place in a school [[fête]] at Willaston County Primary School in [[Willaston, Cheshire East|Willaston]], [[Cheshire]]. The World Worm Charming Championships started in 1980 and is now an annual event that celebrates the sport.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wormcharming.com:80/index.html |archivedate=2016-09-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160912170513/http://www.wormcharming.com/index.html |title=The World Worm Charming Championship |publisher=International Federation of Charming Worms and Allied Pastimes |accessdate=21 October 2018 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> It was organised by then-deputy headmaster John Bailey, who wrote the original rules for the competition.
The current world record was established on June 29, 2009, by 10-year-old Sophie Smith of Willaston, England, who raised 567 worms during Britain's World Worm Charming Championship.<ref name="NewRecord"> {{cite news | title = Worm charmer, 10, sets new record | url = http://www.upi.com/Odd_News/2009/06/29/Worm-charmer-10-sets-new-record/UPI-68561246307679/ | agency = UPI | accessdate = 2009-07-01 }} </ref>
Rules of The British and European Federation of Wormcharmers include a plot no greater than 3 metres by 3 metres, a five-minute warm up period, a three-person team of charmer, catcher and counter and that all worms must be returned to the ground after the contest according to the British Association of Worm Length Supporters (BAWLS).
===Devon Worm Charming Festival=== Also known as the International Festival of Worm Charming, this event takes place in the small village of [[Blackawton]], South Devon, during the early May Bank Holiday. It has been running since 1984 and is accompanied by a [[Real Ale]] [[Beer Festival]] and other activities.
===Canadian Worm Charming Championship and Festival=== The Great Canadian Worm Charming Championship and Festival Canadian Competition was held at the Shelburne Fiddle Park in Shelburne, Ontario, on June 9, 2012.
===American Worm Gruntin' Festival=== The town of [[Sopchoppy, Florida|Sopchoppy]], [[Florida]], has held an annual "Worm Gruntin' Festival" since 2000. The event includes a ball and the crowning of a "Worm Gruntin' King and Queen".<ref name="VisitFlorida">{{cite web |url=http://www.visitflorida.com/en-us/articles/2013/insider--off-the-beaten-path/sopchoppyfestival.html|title=13th Annual Sopchoppy Worm Gruntin' Festival April 13|publisher=Visit Florida}}</ref> Sopchoppy is one of the settings and worm grunting a plot element in the 2017 novel ''Clownfish Blues'' by [[Tim Dorsey]].
